notes:
1. Speed of Sound

The speed of sound ($c$) in an ideal gas depends on its temperature. It is given by:

$$ c = \sqrt{kRT} $$
  • $k$: Specific heat ratio ($c_p/c_v$, approx 1.4 for air).
  • $R$: Specific gas constant (287 J/kg·K for air).
  • $T$: Absolute temperature (Kelvin).

2. Mach Number Definition

The Mach number ($M$) is a dimensionless parameter defined as the ratio of the flow velocity ($V$) to the local speed of sound ($c$).

$$ M = \frac{V}{c} = \frac{V}{\sqrt{kRT}} $$

3. Flow Regimes

  • Subsonic ($M < 1$): Disturbances propagate upstream and downstream. Density changes are often negligible for $M < 0.3$.
  • Sonic ($M = 1$): Flow velocity equals the speed of sound.
  • Supersonic ($M > 1$): Disturbances cannot propagate upstream. Shock waves can form.

solvedExamples.question: Air flows at 200 m/s. The local temperature is 300 K. What is the Mach number? ($k=1.4$, $R=287$ J/kg·K)
solvedExamples.explanation: First calculate the speed of sound: $c = \sqrt{kRT} = \sqrt{1.4 \times 287 \times 300} = \sqrt{120,540} \approx 347.2$ m/s. Then calculate Mach number: $M = V/c = 200 / 347.2 \approx 0.576$.

solvedExamples.question: If the Mach number is 2.0 and the temperature is 250 K, what is the velocity of the air? ($k=1.4$, $R=287$ J/kg·K)
solvedExamples.explanation: Calculate the speed of sound: $c = \sqrt{1.4 \times 287 \times 250} = \sqrt{100,450} \approx 316.9$ m/s. Velocity $V = M \times c = 2.0 \times 316.9 \approx 633.9$ m/s.
